Graphical abstract Bimetallic Rh- and Co-based catalysts are promising materials for the heterogenous ethylene hydroformylation reaction. Here, the influence of a mesoporous silica (SBA-15) support on Rh and Co bimetallic interactions was investigated through a comparison with silica gel and gamma-alumina supports. The bimetallic catalyst supported on mesoporous silica (RhCo3/SBA-15) showed the best C3 oxygenate yield among the three bimetallic catalysts. In-situ vibrational studies suggested moderate binding of the gem-dicarbonyl and Rh(CO)(C2H4) intermediates due to this bimetallic interaction that led to improved hydroformylation performance. Kinetic studies revealed a lower hydroformylation barrier for the bimetallic compared to a Rh monometallic catalyst, and in-situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy investigations showed clear Rh-Co alloy formation on RhCo3/SBA-15. The bimetallic enhancement effect from the interaction with the mesoporous silica support shown here can be further optimized to design olefin hydroformylation catalysts. Keywords Heterogeneous catalyst Hydroformylation Ethylene Bimetallic interactions Mesoporous support effect Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The olefin hydroformylation reaction is an important route for aldehyde production [1,2]. Its mechanism has been widely studied and typically involves the hydrogenation of surface olefin species, followed by CO insertion, and subsequent hydrogenation of the resulting acyl intermediate [3–7]. Hydroformylation is atom-efficient, but hydrogenation and isomerization side reactions can occur that decrease selectivity and result in alkane and olefin production [8]. Compared with current industrial homogeneous liquid-phase processes, which rely on transition metal complexes that are difficult to recover and reuse, heterogeneous olefin hydroformylation is considered to be more sustainable because its use of metals immobilized on solid supports can allow more efficient catalyst recycling [9]. Furthermore, heterogeneous hydroformylation avoids the leaching of precious metals and phosphorous into waste streams, which is a common challenge of the homogenous method [8]. Recent investigations have focused on identifying greener solvents [10] or using supercritical CO2 as the reaction medium to avoid solvent recycling issues [11]. To this end, heterogeneous hydroformylation is a more environmentally friendly method because it avoids the use of solvents entirely. In addition, the gas-phase hydroformylation of ethylene has been demonstrated as a method to directly convert the products of CO2-oxidative alkane dehydrogenation into C3 oxygenates, which represents a promising way to utilize captured CO2 for the production of valuable platform chemicals [12–18]. Investigations in the past have identified promising catalysts for heterogeneous hydroformylation including single-atom Rh catalysts [19], RhZn intermetallic nanoparticles [20], porous polymer-supported Rh catalysts [21], and other mesoporous materials that exploit confinement effects to improve selectivity [22–26]. Overall, Rh- and Co-based materials are promising catalysts for ethylene hydroformylation. The ability of the active Rh species to stabilize the important gem-dicarbonyl intermediate has been well-studied for several decades [27–31] and was recently demonstrated in detail in a theoretical study of Rh/Al2O3 with a ReOx promoter [32]. The active species of Co monometallic catalysts have been less explored [33,34], but Co is known to promote activity in Rh-Co bimetallic catalysts due to increased Rh dispersion and electronic interactions that affect the binding strength between intermediates and active sites [35,36]. Rh-induced enhancement of Co dispersion has also been demonstrated [37]. In addition to bimetallic interactions, the structure and chemical nature of the catalyst support is also an important consideration for olefin hydroformylation. The influence of confinement on olefin hydroformylation has been shown in recent studies [23,38,39]. In particular, confinement effects for 1-octene heterogeneous hydroformylation on Rh complexes have been shown using mesoporous MCM-41 and SBA-15 supports [40], and increased regioselectivity of propylene and hexene hydroformylation was demonstrated by tuning of the microenvironment around an active Rh site through alkali-metal modification and confinement in zeolite pores [22]. Promising propylene hydroformylation performance has also been demonstrated on CoO-supported Rh single atom catalysts [41]. For ethylene hydroformylation, the influence of the support on the activity of single-atom Rh catalysts has been shown in comparisons of different metal oxide supports including one by Farpon et al. [42] focusing on SiO2, ZrO2, CeO2, and SnO2, and another from Amsler et al. [19] comparing MgO and CeO2 supports. Another recent investigation showed modulation of active sites on a Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalyst through functionalization of the support [30]. These previous studies have mainly been focused on monometallic Rh-based catalysts; however, bimetallic Rh-Co materials have generally shown better performance [3,43]. Therefore, elucidation of the influence of mesoporous oxide supports on Rh-Co interactions for heterogeneous ethylene hydroformylation is needed. In this work, the impact of different types of supports on Rh-Co bimetallic effects and how these interactions affect catalyst performance were discerned by comparing monometallic and bimetallic Rh and Co catalysts supported on mesoporous SBA-15 along with silica gel (SiO2) and gamma-alumina (γ-Al2O3). Catalysts were synthesized, then their dispersion and particle size were characterized via CO chemisorption and transmission electron microscopy (TEM), respectively. Flow reactor evaluations were conducted to compare conversion as well as hydroformylation yield and selectivity. Arrhenius plots were then developed to estimate the apparent activation barrier toward the hydroformylation and hydrogenation of ethylene under a transport-free intrinsic kinetic regime. In order to understand surface species formed during the reaction, in-situ diffuse reflectance Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (DRIFTS) measurements were performed. Finally, in-situ X-ray absorption near-edge spectroscopy (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) analyses were done to determine the chemical state and local structure of Rh and Co species under reaction conditions. This work informs the design of hydroformylation catalysts, and furthermore, is broadly applicable to any process that upgrades CO or CO2 into fuels and chemicals because effective C−C coupling is a crucial step in any such reaction. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst Synthesis Catalysts were synthesized by incipient wetness impregnation of Rh(NO3)3·xH2O and Co(NO3)2·6H2O precursors onto SiO2, SBA-15, or γ-Al2O3 (Sigma-Aldrich) supports to achieve 2.9 wt% Rh and 5 wt% Co, corresponding to a Rh/Co atomic ratio of 1/3. To indicate the atomic ratio, Rh, Co3 and RhCo3 were used to represent catalysts containing monometallic Rh, monometallic Co, and bimetallic RhCo, respectively. For example, the 5 wt% Co on SiO2 was labeled as Co3/SiO2, and the bimetallic 2.9 wt% Rh and 5 wt% Co on SiO2 was labeled as RhCo3/SiO2. After impregnation, the catalysts were dried overnight at 70 °C and then calcined in a muffle furnace by heating at a ramping rate of 5 °C min−1 to 500 °C and holding for 2 h. The catalysts were ground into fine powders for CO chemisorption, TEM, and DRIFTS measurements, and they were pressed and passed through 40–60 mesh sieves to prepare 0.25–0.4 mm particles for flow reactor evaluation. 2.2 Characterization The catalysts were characterized by CO chemisorption and TEM. Pulse CO chemisorption measurements were carried out using an Altamira AMI-300ip, with 100 mg of catalyst being loaded into the instrument and reduced at 500 °C before being cooled to 40 °C and exposed to pulses of 10 % CO. Electron microscopy characterization was performed on the fresh and spent catalysts, which were prepared using ultrasonic dispersion of samples in ethanol for 10 min. Subsequently, a droplet of the dispersed sample was placed onto a Lacey carbon film supported by a copper grid and allowed to dry thoroughly. TEM images were captured using a JEOL 1400 instrument. For determining the distribution of Rh and Co elements in the spent catalysts, energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy elemental mapping in scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM-EDS) was performed on a Thermo-Fisher Talos F200X. 2.3 In-situ X-ray absorption XANES and EXAFS measurements at the Rh K-edge and Co K-edge were performed at beamline 7-BM (QAS) at the National Synchrotron Light Source II. For the in-situ Rh K-edge experiments, 100 mg of either Rh/SBA-15 or RhCo3/SBA-15 powder were pressed into a 13 mm diameter pellet, which was loaded into a Nashner-Adler cell. For the reduction treatment, the catalyst was heated to 500 °C in N2/H2 (20/5 ml min−1) and held until the spectrum stabilized. Following this, the catalyst was cooled to 160 °C and a flow of N2/C2H4/CO/H2 (10/10/10/10 ml min−1) was introduced to characterize the catalyst under hydroformylation reaction conditions. These were again held until the spectrum appeared to stabilize. To compare the chemical state of Rh in the catalysts to that of metallic Rh and Rh oxide, ex-situ measurements of Rh foil and Rh2O3 were also performed. The same procedure was used for in-situ Co K-edge measurements of Co3/SBA-15 and RhCo3/SBA-15. 2.4 Flow reactor experiments For the initial comparison of ethylene conversion and oxygenate yield, 200 mg of catalyst (40–60 mesh) was loaded into a quartz tube reactor and reduced in a flow of Ar/H2 (10/10 ml min−1) and heated to 500 °C at a rate of 9.5 °C min−1, then held for 1 h before cooling to the reaction temperature of 160 °C. After the temperature stabilized, the reactant gas mixture of Ar/H2/C2H4/CO (3/3/3/3 ml min−1) was introduced. For the comparison of selectivity, modifications of the total catalyst mass were made to achieve more comparable conversion below 9 %. Interparticle dilution with SiO2 was used for the Rh/SBA-15, RhCo3/SiO2, RhCo3/SBA-15, and RhCo3/γ-Al2O3 catalysts (dilution ratios were shown in Table S2) to achieve steady state conversion of 4.1–9.0 %. Due to the intrinsically lower activity of Co-based catalysts, the conversion of C2H4 over these catalysts remained low, between 0.9 % and 3.1 %, despite increasing the catalyst weight from 200 mg to 800 mg. Apparent activation barrier measurements for Rh/SBA-15 and RhCo3/SBA-15 were carried out in the temperature range of 140–170 °C and step size of 10 °C with an increased reactant flow rate of Ar/H2/C2H4/CO (10/10/10/10 ml min−1) to avoid mass transport effects. The catalyst loading was adjusted (Table S3) to result in conversion between 1.4 % and 8.5 %. 2.5 DRIFTS measurements In-situ DRIFTS experiments were conducted using a Nicolet 6700 spectrometer. Powder catalysts were loaded into the cell and reduced under a flow of H2/He (5/45 ml min−1) at 500 °C for 1 h, and then cooled to 25 °C or 160 °C depending on the type of experiment. Once the temperature stabilized, 50 ml min−1 of 10 % CO was introduced for 30 min. For the room temperature experiments, this was followed by an 80 min He purge. For the measurements at 160 °C, the 10 % CO exposure was followed sequentially by purging with He for 60 min, flowing 50 ml min−1 of 10 % C2H4 for 30 min, then purging with He for 60 min while continuously collecting IR spectra at 1 min intervals to track the evolution of surface intermediates over time. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Dispersion and particle size characterization CO chemisorption measurements were performed to elucidate differences in the Rh and Co dispersion on the three different supports. Table S1 showed the CO uptake along with results from the catalyst performance evaluation, and Figure S1 showed the normalized CO thermal conductivity detector peak area as a function of the CO pulse number. The monometallic Rh catalysts displayed the highest CO uptake (above 120 μmol g−1), which decreased on the bimetallic RhCo3 catalysts for all three supports, potentially due to Rh being partially covered by the high Co loading. The Rh/γ-Al2O3 and RhCo3/γ-Al2O3 catalysts showed the highest overall CO uptake, and Figure S1 showed more significant CO adsorption during the initial CO pulses on the γ-Al2O3-supported catalysts compared with those on SiO2 and SBA-15. The monometallic Co3 catalysts displayed negligible CO uptake, which was likely due to Co being in a partially oxidized state, as shown for Co3/SBA-15 via XANES analysis (Figure S8). In order to further characterize the physical properties of the Rh- and Co-based catalysts, TEM measurements were performed. Fig. 1 showed the TEM images of the fresh, as-synthesized catalysts. The Co showed a much smaller particle size on the SBA-15 support (5.7 nm) compared to when it was supported on SiO2 (87 nm) or γ-Al2O3 (14 nm). SBA-15 was also unique in that it showed clear ordering of the nanoparticles into the mesopores for all three active metal species. In addition, the Co dispersion appeared to be significantly improved for the bimetallic catalysts compared to monometallic Co3 due to the lower particle size of the former, which was consistent with previous findings comparing Co and RhCo supported on Al2O3 [37]. This could partially explain the improved bimetallic interactions and enhanced catalyst performance, as discussed in Section 3.2. TEM images of the spent SBA-15-supported samples were displayed in Figure S2, showing some agglomeration of Co in the monometallic Co3/SBA-15, but negligible changes in the particle size of the metal species in either of the Rh-based catalysts. Additionally, the particle sizes of Rh/SBA-15 and RhCo3/SBA-15 were similar, allowing the examination of the bimetallic effect by excluding size effects. High-angle annular dark field (HAADF) and STEM-EDS measurements of the RhCo3/SiO2 and RhCo3/SBA-15 catalysts were also performed (Fig. 2 ). The HAADF images clearly showed improved dispersion and smaller particle size for the active metal species on RhCo3/SBA-15 compared to RhCo3/SiO2. The elemental mapping via STEM-EDS suggested close proximity of Co and Rh atoms on both catalysts, suggesting that both formed bimetallic Rh-Co active species. However, the Rh species in RhCo3/SBA-15 appeared to be smaller with minimal agglomeration compared to the SiO2 support, which showed larger clusters of concentrated Rh and Co species. Such differences suggested that the SBA-15 support led to a suppression of the formation of large Co particles, enhancing the bimetallic interactions between Rh and Co. 3.2 Catalyst evaluation To elucidate the effects of different support materials on Rh-Co bimetallic interactions, activity evaluations were conducted at 160 °C for Rh, Co3, and RhCo3 catalysts supported on SiO2, SBA-15, and γ-Al2O3, as summarized in Table S1. The conversion versus time-on-stream (Fig. 3 b) showed that the reaction reached steady-state after approximately 6 h, without significant deactivation afterwards. The highest C2H4 conversion of 46.8 % was observed on the RhCo3/SBA-15 catalyst, followed by a conversion of 25.2 % over RhCo3/γ-Al2O3. When comparing the active metal species, the bimetallic catalyst had the highest conversion on all three supports, following the order of Co3 < Rh < RhCo3, consistent with a bimetallic enhancement. Between the three supports, the SBA-15-supported catalysts displayed significantly higher C2H4 conversion than their counterparts supported on either SiO2 or γ-Al2O3. The total C3 oxygenate yield (Fig. 3a, Table S1) was dependent on both the active metal species and the oxide support. For all three supports, the C3 oxygenate yield over the bimetallic RhCo3 was significantly higher than the sum of the yield over the corresponding monometallic Co3 and Rh catalysts, indicating that there were beneficial interactions between Rh and Co species. Furthermore, the increase in yield could not be attributed to a Co-induced enhancement of Rh dispersion, as the CO uptake was shown to decrease by a factor of 1.5 on the RhCo3/SBA-15 compared with Rh/SBA-15. Among each metal, the SBA-15 support showed a significant enhancement of C3 oxygenate yield compared with SiO2 and γ-Al2O3, which again could not be attributed to an increase in CO uptake, as the highest CO uptake was observed on the γ-Al2O3-supported catalysts of both monometallic and bimetallic Rh-based materials. Comparing RhCo3 supported on SiO2 and SBA-15, the CO uptake showed a minimal increase from 76 μmol g−1 to 81 μmol g−1, while the C3 oxygenate yield more than doubled, increasing from 9.4 % to 20.4 %. This result suggested that an increase in metal dispersion alone was not responsible for the improved hydroformylation performance, which was instead attributed to stabilization of important reaction intermediates that will be discussed in Section 3.3. Moreover, this agreed with the enhanced bimetallic interactions over the SBA-15 support that were revealed by the improved proximity between Rh and Co observed in the STEM-EDS images. The lowest propanal to propanol ratio of 1.2 was observed on the RhCo3/SBA-15 catalyst, while it was 5.6 and 1.9 on the RhCo3/SiO2 and RhCo3/γ-Al2O3 catalysts, respectively, indicating that the nature of the support also affected the subsequent hydrogenation of propanal to propanol. To assess the influence of the different supports and active metal species on the hydroformylation selectivity at more comparable conversion, the evaluation was conducted under modified conditions to reach steady-state conversion below 9 % for all catalysts, and therefore measure the intrinsic selectivity with minimal influence from transport effects. The results from this comparison were shown in Fig. 4 , and the conversion and reaction conditions were given in Table S2. When comparing the active metal species, the intrinsic selectivity showed the same trend as the C3 oxygenate yield (Co3 < Rh < RhCo3). The support appeared to have much less influence on the C3 oxygenate selectivity of the bimetallic RhCo3 catalyst at lower conversion than it did on the yield at higher conversion, with selectivity ranging from 46.7 % on RhCo3/γ-Al2O3 to 54.1 % on RhCo3/SiO2. The fact that the mesoporous SBA-15 did not show enhanced performance in this comparison revealed that the mesopores of the support played a much more important role under high conversion conditions. The selectivities for propanal and propanol (Figure S4) over different catalysts, as well as the relationship between their selectivities (Figure S5) were compared in the Supporting Information. As shown in Figure S4, the selectivity for propanol was much lower compared to that for propanal, indicating that the subsequent hydrogenation of propanal was not significant under the tested conditions. When correlating the selectivities of propanal with those of propanol (Figure S5), a few interesting observations emerged: (1) there was no linear correlation between the selectivities for propanal and propanol. (2) Catalysts containing Co appeared to favor the secondary hydrogenation of propanal to propanol. Among the monometallic Co-based catalysts, Co3/SBA-15 and Co3/SiO2 exhibited higher selectivities for propanol at 4.5 % and 3.2 %, respectively, compared to 1.0 % for the Co3/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. This variation might stem from the silica-supported Co species, which were more readily reduced to the metallic phase than those supported by γ-Al2O3, with the metallic Co phase favoring the hydrogenation of propanal. (3) In contrast, Rh-based catalysts typically demonstrated lower selectivity for propanol than Co-based catalysts. Specifically, Rh/SBA-15 and Rh/SiO2 showed no selectivity for propanol. (4) The propanol selectivity of the RhCo-based catalysts on the three types of supports ranged from 3.2 % to 4.6 %, likely due to the presence of the metallic Co phase promoted by the reduction of Rh, thus providing a relatively higher propanol selectivities. To understand the influence of kinetics on the differences in selectivity and yield that were observed over the Rh-based, SBA-15-supported catalysts, Arrhenius plots were constructed to compare the apparent activation barriers (Eapp, Fig. 5 ). The Eapp toward hydroformylation (C3 oxygenate formation) and hydrogenation (C2H6 formation) were 92 ± 1.1 kJ/mol and 58 ± 1.6 kJ/mol on Rh/SBA-15 (Fig. 5a) and on RhCo3/SBA-15 (Fig. 5b), respectively. Specifically, a more significant 14 % decrease in the hydroformylation barrier (ΔEapp = -8 kJ/mol) relative to a 4 % decrease in the hydrogenation barrier (ΔEapp = -4 kJ/mol) when going from Rh/SBA-15 to RhCo3/SBA-15 suggested that more favorable hydroformylation kinetics played a role in the increased C3 oxygenate selectivity on the bimetallic catalyst. 3.3 DRIFTS studies of surface intermediates To further clarify the influence of the mesoporous SBA-15 support and its effect on the Rh-Co interactions, DRIFTS measurements following CO and C2H4 exposure at 160 °C were performed. Fig. 6 showed the ν(CO) region (2150–1950 cm−1) of the spectra under different experimental conditions, and Figure S6 showed the 1750–1200 cm−1 and 3300–2700 cm−1 regions for the same catalysts during the C2H4 exposure. Three major peaks were identified and assigned to four different CO species. The peaks in the ranges of 2085–2091 and 2014–2033 cm−1 were attributed to the symmetric and asymmetric stretching modes, respectively, of the gem-dicarbonyl (Rh(CO)2) species, and the peaks in the range of 2063–2069 cm−1 were assigned to the stretching mode of linearly bonded CO on Rh, (Table S4) [3,36,44]. In addition, the 2014–2049 cm−1 peak likely had contributions from the ν(CO) mode of Rh(CO)(H) and Rh(CO)(C2H4) species for some of the catalysts under certain reaction conditions [44–48]. The observation of the Rh gem-dicarbonyl bands has often been interpreted as supporting the presence of Rh single atoms. However, recent publications have reported the coexistence of Rh gem-dicarbonyl bands and linearly bonded CO bands in CO-DRIFTS spectra, when the corresponding TEM measurements indicated the presence of Rh clusters or nanoparticles [27,36,49,50]. It remains unclear whether this coexistence suggests the simultaneous presence of both Rh single atoms and Rh nanoparticles, or if it reflects the presence of Rh clusters or nanoparticles with different Rh atoms exhibiting distinct behaviors, such as those located on terraces, edges, kinks, or corners with varying coordination numbers. The definitive distinction would need to be further investigated. In the current study, we tentatively assigned the observation of the Rh gem-dicarbonyl bands to unsaturated Rh species in nanoparticles for further discussion, as both TEM measurements (2–5 nm, Fig. 1) and in-situ EXAFS studies (Fig. 7 ) suggested the presence of Rh nanoparticles. During the CO exposure (Fig. 6a), the intensities of the gem-dicarbonyl peaks were higher on Rh/SBA-15 compared with RhCo3/SBA-15, suggesting that the lower C3 oxygenate selectivity on the monometallic catalyst could be at least partially due to over-stabilization of the Rh(CO)2 species that hindered co-adsorption of CO and C2H4. This was supported by DRIFTS measurements at 25 °C (Figure S7) of the SiO2- and SBA-15-supported catalysts that showed more intense CO peaks on the monometallic Rh compared with the bimetallic catalysts, consistent with the quantification in the CO pulse experiments. For the experiments at 160 °C after a 60 min He purge (Fig. 6b), the linearly bonded CO stretch was no longer visible on any of the catalysts, indicating that this species had desorbed. Additionally, attenuation of the gem-dicarbonyl modes was much more pronounced on the RhCo3/SBA-15 compared with RhCo3/γ-Al2O3, further supporting the hypothesis that more weakly bound Rh(CO)2 species were beneficial to the increased hydroformylation activity of RhCo3/SBA-15. On the other hand, the decrease in the intensity of the gem-dicarbonyl peaks on RhCo3/SBA-15 was not as significant as that on RhCo3/SiO2, suggesting that moderate stabilization of Rh(CO)2 species was optimal for hydroformylation. After flowing C2H4 for 30 min (Fig. 6c), the RhCo3/SBA-15 spectrum uniquely showed the disappearance of the peak at 2094 cm−1 along with the presence of a peak at 2025 cm−1, which was attributed to the Rh(CO)(C2H4) species due to the existence of a ν(C=C) peak at 1564 cm−1 (Figure S6). On the other hand, the Rh/SBA-15 catalyst displayed the presence of both νs(CO) and νas(CO) modes and did not show a peak attributed to the ν(C=C) mode. This suggested an improved ability of RhCo3/SBA-15 to co-adsorb CO and C2H4 compared to Rh/SBA-15, through the facile replacement of one CO molecule with C2H4-derived surface species. The resulting Rh(CO)(C2H4) or hydrogenated Rh(CO)(C2H5) species is considered an important intermediate, as the CO ligand facilitates insertion into the Rh-C2H5 bond, followed by hydrogenation to produce propanal [36]. Thus, the easy replacement of one CO molecule with C2H4-derived species likely lead to an improved CO insertion ability of the bimetallic catalyst and thus an increased hydroformylation yield observed in the flow reactor evaluation. Overall, the DRIFTS results indicated that the mesoporous SBA-15 support facilitated bimetallic Rh-Co interactions that stabilized Rh species with moderate binding strength to gem-dicarbonyl CO moieties. Furthermore, the detection of Rh(CO)(C2H4) over the bimetallic catalyst showed that CO could more readily exchange with C2H4 species compared to the monometallic catalyst, leading to enhanced hydroformylation selectivity and yield. 3.4 In-situ X-ray absorption measurements To differentiate the chemical state and local structure of Rh species in the SBA-15-supported catalysts, in-situ XANES and EXAFS measurements were conducted under reduction and reaction conditions for the Rh/SBA-15 and RhCo3/SBA-15 catalysts at the Rh K-edge (Fig. 7) and for Co3/SBA-15 and RhCo3/SBA-15 catalysts at the Co K-edge (Figure S8). The similarity of the Rh K-edge XANES spectra (Fig. 7a) of Rh/SBA-15 and RhCo3/SBA-15 catalysts to that of the Rh foil spectrum suggested that the majority of Rh was metallic upon reduction. During the reduction, the monometallic Rh/SBA-15 spectrum showed slightly higher peak energy than the Rh foil profile, suggesting a higher oxidation state of Rh in the catalyst compared to the foil. Comparably, due to the presence of Co, the Rh absorption energy of RhCo3/SBA-15 was slightly higher than that of Rh/SBA-15, in agreement with previous results on RhCo3/MCM-41 [12]. This slightly higher oxidation state of Rh was consistent with the more optimal stabilization of Rh(CO)(C2H4) species on RhCo3/SBA-15 that was observed in the DRIFTS measurements. Furthermore, there was attenuation and broadening of the higher-energy scattering peak intensities of RhCo3/SBA-15 compared with Rh/SBA-15, which was ascribed to Rh-Co alloy formation considering that both samples had similar particle sizes (Fig. 1). During the hydroformylation reaction, the XANES spectra of Rh/SBA-15 and RhCo3/SBA-15 both displayed slight changes compared with those under reduction conditions, suggesting that the dominant Rh species in the catalyst remained stable during the hydroformylation reaction, and the minor changes were attributed to the adsorption of reaction intermediates on the surface atoms. This further supported the hypothesis that the main active sites are the unsaturated Rh atoms on the surface of metal nanoparticles, consistent with the in-situ DRIFTS results. The Co K-edge (Figure S8) measurements showed a much more facile reduction of Co in the RhCo3/SBA-15 catalyst compared with Co3/SBA-15 due to the presence of Rh in the bimetallic catalyst. The partially oxidized state of Co in the monometallic catalyst was consistent with its low CO uptake despite the small particle size that was observed via TEM. The EXAFS fitting (Figure S9) at the Rh K-edge provided additional information on the coordination number (CN) and bond distance (d) for Rh/SBA-15 and RhCo3/SBA-15 catalysts under reaction conditions. As shown in Table S5, the EXAFS fitting of Rh/SBA-15 revealed values of CNRh-Rh = 7.9, dRh-Rh = 2.69 Å, and CNRh-C=0.8, dRh-C=1.86 Å. Note that the EXAFS feature observed at shorter distances (<2.0 Å) could be assigned to be either Rh-O or Rh-C bond. However, given the metallic phase feature in the XANES spectra and the DRIFTS detection of surface carbon-containing species such as CO or C2H4 during the reaction, the possibility of Rh-O bond was ruled out, confirming the existence of Rh-C bonds. Similarly, the EXAFS fitting of RhCo3/SBA-15 showed CNRh-Co = 3.7, dRh-Rh = 2.57 Å, CNRh-Rh = 4.9, dRh-Rh = 2.66 Å, and CNRh-C=0.5, dRh-C=1.84 Å. These findings substantiated the formation of Rh-Co alloy, and the observation of similar total CNs of Rh in both Rh/SBA-15 and RhCo3/SBA-15 correlated with their comparable particle sizes. In addition, the lower CN of Rh-C in RhCo3/SBA-15 compared to Rh/SBA-15 suggested a reduced surface intermediate coverage, aligning well with the results from the pulse CO chemisorption measurements and DRIFTS results over these two catalysts. 4 Conclusions This work has demonstrated the ability of the RhCo3/SBA-15 catalyst to facilitate the hydroformylation reaction with promising C3 oxygenate yield and selectivity, and identified how the mesoporous SBA-15 support influenced Rh-Co interactions to stabilize important surface species. Improved Rh-Co bimetallic interactions due to SBA-15 were suggested by the significant improvement in C3 oxygenate yield over RhCo3/SBA-15 compared to their counterparts supported on SiO2 and γ-Al2O3. The C3 oxygenate yield on RhCo3/SBA-15 was a factor of 2.2 higher than the RhCo3/SiO2, and a factor of 3.1 higher than the monometallic Rh/SBA-15. This was likely due to improved proximity between Rh and Co species and minimal agglomeration due to the mesoporous structure of the SBA-15 as observed in HAADF and STEM-EDS images. Furthermore, the fact that the C3 oxygenate yield was higher on the bimetallic catalyst despite lower CO uptake indicated that metal dispersion did not have a strong influence on the catalyst activity. Therefore, the optimal activity of the RhCo3/SBA-15 catalyst was attributed to modifications of the Rh active sites that could stabilize important intermediates, which were observed using DRIFTS measurements. Specifically, the intermediate intensity of the Rh(CO)2 species and stabilization of Rh(CO)(C2H4) on RhCo3/SBA-15 indicated that the gem-dicarbonyl was bound neither too strongly or too weakly, and could readily exchange CO and C2H4 species to generate important reaction intermediates and ultimately enhance the CO insertion activity. The apparent activation barrier toward hydroformylation was found to be 8 kJ/mol lower for RhCo3/SBA-15 compared with monometallic Rh/SBA-15, indicating that kinetic effects played a role in the improved yield and selectivity of the bimetallic catalyst. Overall, the comparison of monometallic and bimetallic catalysts on different supports showed the importance of enhancing bimetallic interactions to facilitate moderate binding with carbonyl moieties to improve the C3 oxygenate yield. coredata.dc:description: Bimetallic Rh- and Co-based catalysts are promising materials for the heterogenous ethylene hydroformylation reaction. Here, the influence of a mesoporous silica (SBA-15) support on Rh and Co bimetallic interactions was investigated through a comparison with silica gel and gamma-alumina supports. The bimetallic catalyst supported on mesoporous silica (RhCo3/SBA-15) showed the best C3 oxygenate yield among the three bimetallic catalysts. In-situ vibrational studies suggested moderate binding of the gem-dicarbonyl and Rh(CO)(C2H4) intermediates due to this bimetallic interaction that led to improved hydroformylation performance. Kinetic studies revealed a lower hydroformylation barrier for the bimetallic compared to a Rh monometallic catalyst, and in-situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy investigations showed clear Rh-Co alloy formation on RhCo3/SBA-15. The bimetallic enhancement effect from the interaction with the mesoporous silica support shown here can be further optimized to design olefin hydroformylation catalysts.
